facts: Lightning is five times hotter than the surface of the Sun.
A bolt of lightning can travel at speeds of up to 270,000 mph.
Lightning strikes Earth about 100 times every second - that's 8.6 million times per day.
Thunder is the sound of lightning - the flash heats air so fast it explodes outward.
You can tell how far away lightning is by counting seconds between flash and thunder - divide by 5 for miles.
Lightning bolts can be up to 5 miles long.
The energy in one lightning bolt could toast 100,000 slices of bread.
Positive lightning strikes from the top of clouds and is much more powerful than negative lightning.
Lightning can occur in volcanic eruptions, creating 'dirty thunderstorms'.
Ball lightning is a rare phenomenon where glowing spheres float through the air during storms.
The Empire State Building is struck by lightning about 25 times per year.
Lightning creates ozone, which you can sometimes smell after a storm.
A person struck by lightning doesn't remain electrified - it's safe to touch them.
Lightning can forge glass tubes called fulgurites when it strikes sand or rock.
The odds of being struck by lightning in your lifetime are about 1 in 15,300.
Catatumbo Lightning in Venezuela produces lightning 260 nights per year, up to 280 times per hour.
Lightning causes about $1 billion in property damage in the United States each year.
The ancient Greeks believed lightning was a weapon thrown by Zeus, king of the gods.
